# Draft:George Ward

tags — this information should ideally be removed or cited. I've also checked some of the sources, and am having trouble finding where they verify the article's text in several places. For instance, the book The Irishman in Canada does not appear to contain the subject's date or place of birth. Please make sure that everything in this draft is based on what is contained in reliable sources, and remove anything for which you cannot find a source. If you have any questions, just let me know, or you can try asking for help at the Teahouse. MCE89 (talk) 07:21, 16 November 2025 (UTC)}}
----
George Ward (17xx–1837) was a career soldier in the British Army, an early settler of Upper Canada, and the founder of the village of Wardsville, Ontario.
Early life
George Ward was born in 17xx in Queen’s County (now County Laois), Ireland.
Ward "joined the British Army about the close of the last century."  [His British Army service record has not yet been located in surviving archival sources.]
He was married to Margaret Shaw (17xx–1830).
Settlement in Upper Canada
During the American Revolutionary War, Ward served with the British Army and was stationed in Quebec. After completing his military service, he moved west into Upper Canada, which had been created as a separate colony in 1791.
An early settler in the Lower Thames River Valley, Ward received land through the Crown’s grant system in 1794 His property stood in the Long Woods at the junction of Paint Creek and a long-established Indigenous trail , where he was authorized to operate a waystation known as Ward’s Station.
Ward’s presence is documented from 1794 onward through a series of Crown land certificates and petitions.
Ward’s Station
In the early nineteenth century, colonial authorities improved the Indigenous trail into the Longwoods Road. It became the only overland route between the military base of Fort Malden and the adminitrative base of London. Situated roughly midway between these two sites, Ward’s Station became a regular stopping place for travellers and military traffic, including during the War of 1812.
War of 1812
Ward had four sons: William (1794–1851), James (1795–1812), Alexander Daniel (1802-1876), and Talbot St John (1804–1878).
The two eldest, William and James, served in the War of 1812 under Captain John McGregor in the Loyal Kent Militia. James died from illness contracted while stationed at Burlington Heights in 1812. William Ward took part in the Battle of Longwoods on March 4, 1814.
Alexander, still a child during the war, later recalled running with his younger brother, Talbot, through an encampment of Tecumseh and his warriors shortly before the Battle of the Thames on October 5, 1813.
During the American advance following the Battle of the Thames, buildings along the Longwoods Road were burned by American forces. Contemporary accounts record that Ward’s house and waystation were among those destroyed during the retreat.
Death and commemoration
George Ward died in 1837 in Wardsville, Ontario. He is buried in the Wardsville Municipal Cemetery, where the family monument records that he and his wife Margaret were “the first settlers in this district and from whom the village derives its name.”
The Historic Military Establishments of Upper Canada later recognized George—and his sons William and James—for their service in the War of 1812 with a commemorative plaque placed in the Wardsville Municipal Cemetery.
Wardsville and family legacy
The stopping place established by Ward at Paint Creek grew to become the community known as Wardsville. It is not a permanent village in Middlesex County.
Misidentification
George Ward—the founder of Wardsville—has been erroneously confused with men of the same name who served in other military units during the Revolutionary era. [His British Army service record has not yet been located in surviving archival sources.]
References
Further reading

* Hamil, Fred C. The Valley of the Lower Thames 1640 to 1850. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1951.
* McGee, Thomas D’Arcy. The Irishman in Canada. Montreal: Lovell Printing & Publishing Co., 1877.
